comments.commentBody:
Private health insurance companies have failed to deliver to Americans low-cost medicines and drugs via competitive capitalistic bidding, even with massive federal Part D subsidies. With no real interest in our future health, the private health insurance industry has failed to contribute to meaningful medical or clinical research.
The private health insurance industry has needed massive taxpayer subsidies. It would not be profitable without a federal exemption from antitrust laws combined with a federal ban on collective bargaining by physicians. The private insurance companies would not be able to ration health care for profit without a federal law protecting the companies from malpractice lawsuits.
Health insurance companies can only claim success in diverting hundreds of billions of dollars of public and private money from health care providers and patients to profits and payoffs for their bondholders, shareholders, executives and political patrons.
If any other American industry failed to competitively and profitably provide a quality product for all Americans for 40 years, it would either be outsourced to an emerging nation, or shut down.

Billionaires that pay little or no taxes, big corporations that pay little or no taxes, big oil subsidies, big pharmaceutical subsidies, big bank bailouts, big farm subsidies, big bank interest free loans from the Treasury, big defense giveaways, etc., are killing our nation.  The handouts and free ride need to stop before it is too late!
Well, you know, it was necessary for them to prove that government is inherently incompetent.

So-called fiscal conservatives think like Cheney: "deficits don't matter"; so long as they're republican deficits.

A key point: all of this panic about deficits is meaningless–when our economy's problem is one of lack of consumer demand.

We're not "going the way of Greece". We have our own currency. We finance our own debt in our own currency at ~0% interest. There are no bond vigilantes threatening the U.S. with financial ruin.

Republicans are ginning up fears of deficits to shrink parts of government that they despise– any New Deal or Great Society, like Social Security, Medicare, Medicaid and FoodShare.

The best way to reduce the deficit–put people to work. The best way to put people to work is to pump money into the economy, directing the funds to people who need to spend the money for life needs.

Which explains why the R$R, Romney-Ryan "Richie Rich" ticket's propose to cut spending on retirement, healthcare, and food for middle & low-income people–instead diverting those costs to even larger tax cuts for the already rich don't create jobs.

The rich don't need to spend or invest money to create domestic jobs. As corporations are doing domestically, rich people are sitting on their hoards of cash, because there isn't enough domestic demand = consumers' money from middle- and low-income people's purchases to justify domestic investment.

A happy exception– the U.S. auto industry, whose carcass' Romney would've left to the equity-fund "vultures" like himself.

N.,

The President proved to be very capable of doing that himself with some help from his own appointees!

That is why he always asks about someone else's taxes and never talks about his own record!

A question, if you had a great record in a job would you talk about it?

Now, many Republican members of Congress fear a backlash from angry senior citizens over Ryans plan to eliminate Medicare? I hope this November, many of them lose their cushy jobs and benefits.

They're nothing but a lazy, and selfish bunch of cowards that have done nothing over the past four-years to help the average American get out of the awful mess that we're in. But worked very hard at one thing -- trying to make President Obama look bad.

R&R have no intention of securing, protecting, strengthening Medicare. Those are talking points, brilliant right wing spin foisted on unsuspecting or uninformed voters to get their way to slash, burn and shred the safety nets that they and their families most likely will never have to use.

I don't think Citizens United is going to have the power we thought it would. People hear, read, think. Money can't stop that. The nastiness of the ad campaign is going to make people stop watching.
I don't have a TV so I'm immune. Even so, 2 1/2 months of this is more than many want to watch.

Barbi:    People may "hear, read, think" but *what* do they hear or read {or watch]?  Murdoch's Fox networks?  NY Daily News?  I fear that Citzens United will destroy what's already in shreds of U.S. democracy unless it's overturned within a few years (and it's going to take alot of work and time to to do this).

Paul Ryan's voucher system to buy health insurance from a for-profit business is a scam to get rid of Medicare.  Democrats have always championed Medicare.  Republicans have always tried to destroy it.  Let's hope that Citizens United will not allow the Republicans to buy out Medicare.

@Paul, great points. I agree with your observations. I wonder if there is a way to change the situation. Like, is there a way to persuade grown women to watch sports regularly? It's a massively untapped market with a lot of dollars.

At one point, I was a season ticket holder for Sky Blue, Red Bulls, and Philly Indepence within one calendar year. Going to both men and women's games, the major difference I noticed was how organised the crowds were at Red Bull. Sometimes the ardor of the Red Bulls fans was so disproportional to the quality displayed on the field that it was frankly just awkward. In some games, people didn't really care what was going on in the field, it was about how much noise they could make. Perhaps for men, cheering for a team is a socially acceptable bonding tool, while for women, it's shopping.

If there is a way to make watching women's soccer a socially approved bonding tool for women, that's the new league right there.

It is very clear that Mr. Ryan is an ideologue. He is for his "truth" and the "right" way. Mr. Ryan proposes vouchers, but also proposes insurance companies to craft their own plans --without the regulation of the government. Mr. Ryan is not dumb. He knows that in such a world a myriad of plans would be pitiful and inappropriate in coverage. He knows that seniors of moderate means will have to face the prospect of totally insufficient coverage and inferior medical care.

And, Mr. Ryan relishes such outcomes... In his Randian world those that did not appropriate for themselves a good-sized pot of gold thoroughly deserve their misfortune. In the philosophy of "Atlas Shrugged" (and of far right fascist fantasies) those that did not make themselves rich and self-sufficient (by any means: obviously allying oneself to a government-funded pension and a gold plated congressional unlimited all expenses paid healthcare plan is OK) deserve their lot.

Mr. Ryan knows very well that his Medicare plan is thoroughly inadequate. He knows very well too that his budget proposals do not add up and will explode the deficit while preserving tax cuts for the rich and mountains of money to military contractors. He knows all of this and cherishes the result of a cut-throat world where the meek are crushed by those with money and power.

Mr. Ryan, and Mr. Romney, believe, you see, that those who own this country ought to govern it, and they see themselves as owners and everybody else as losers.

Agreed.  Allowing the insurance industry to "manage itself" through "managed care" has proven NOT to decrease spending costs NOR increase efficiency.  The venture capitalist vultures have turned medical care provision into a lucrative, self-serving, CEO millionare creating nightmare.

I am sorry that you have not gotten a sponsorship. H1B is really a separate unrelated immigration issue. These people are not competing for highly skilled and highly educated positions. They did not come here out of choice but they sure do not want to leave either. This is the only place they really know. At least most H1B visa denials have a "home" in their home country. This is the only "home" for these aliens. What is your masters in? Is there a shortage of people for your field? If your masters is in nursing you would get a job for sure. Or if just an RN you'd get an H1C.  It's really demanding work but a way in for lots of people because there is always a nursing shortage.

my question is for anyone that approves of these laws.  Do you think there should be a ban of alcohol because adults like to drink and drive which ends up killing people.  Imagine all the lives that could be saved from banning alcohol.  I don't advocate either law but everyone should understand that not every teenager is a wreckless driver just like every adult is not a drunk driver.
The older drivers paid for the roads, call it entitlement.

This is another example of generational warfare. Consider that statistically speaking an older driver is more dangerous than even the most dangerous teen (http://www.fhwa.dot.gov/policyinformation/statistics/2007/nhts1231.cfm and this is after a dramatic drop in older driver accidents in the last decade) however there are more teens, and they do not vote. By all means restrict teenage driving based on stats, if one does so for older drivers as well. Otherwise, stats are being used to discriminate, in which case they are excuses, not facts.

You will notice there's no movement to have stickers for older drivers, anywhere, or mandatory license turn ins.
SP I believe LA Lawyer is on your side!  He called HCA profiteers in effect.
Thinking about it may be the cause of your chest pains.

Private equity firms should not be running hospitals.
Please remind me of this next time I have chest pains.

This is everything that's wrong with health care in the United States.   A basic human service that everyone needs does not reconcile with the bloodsucking setup that is capitalism.  Obamacare won't help, because every facet of our existence revolves around the exploitation of others for pecuniary gain.  It is rewarded.  It is celebrated.  It is our way of life.  And it is sickening.

"It's despicable that our health is now in the hands of bankers."

Along with everything else.

One other thing - my daughter fell off a bike in Ecuador - she got multiple stitches - when I asked if she had to give her travel insurance information, she was surprised I even asked the question - even when she got back to Quito and the stitches were removed there was no bill - and this is in a country we Americans consider "third world"
It's despicable that our health is now in the hands of bankers.

Wake up America! This is what were going to get with Health Care for Profit,and everyone knows it! People better get these kind of People out of Government or leave the Country! This Country was built on Socialization! With anything else this Country is doomed!!
If the only good thing for for-profit hospitals bring is capital -- but do lots of evil -- then government needs to step in and bring more capital.  We don't need evil in our health care system.

No. They are not a necessary evil. They are evil parasites that flourish from the suffering of the sick. All of these advances that you point to are more abundant and cheaper in France and Canada, where everyone has Medicare. And they pay less than 50% for their healthcare.
I will not read your book. I am a Registered Nurse. We do not consider profit or the ability to pay. We care for everyone.

All evidence points to the fact that for profit is a mistake. Also, having a private insurance system that cherry picks in tandem with this system is basically a recipe for the stats that are quoted in the article about costs and life expectancy. It is tantamount to murder.

I'm working on a history of the for-prof hospital biz. When I asked HCA co-founder Tommy Frist how he and co-investors could justify taking billions out of the company in dividends, he replied that if an enterprise the size of HCA were a non-profit, it would have paid just as much or more to banks for debt financing as it paid him and others for equity.

An intriguing assertion. I have not been able to find an objective way to judge its validity.

Unmentioned in comments on this story: For-profit chains have brought capital into the hospital sector in quantities vastly beyond what government or charity could bring on their own. Advances in medical technology in the past 50 years required huge capital layouts.

The federal government tried for decades after WWII to get decent hospital care to underserved communities thru Hill-Burton Act, but HCA et al. arguably had more success in their first years than Hill-Burton had over decades.

My book will mention plenty of horror stories -- HCA, yes, but others too. Can't resist mentioning: When dialysis profiteer National Medical Care sold to Fresenius in 1998, the buyer abruptly abandoned its interest in a clinic NMC had set up in China -- after learning foreign transplant patients at the facility may have been “receiving kidney organs harvested from executed Chinese criminals.”

Still, if for-profits are evil (& I'm not saying so re any case), are they a necessary evil?

--Tom Wood
Healthcare history page: http://on.fb.me/4profhc

Hollywood feeds us with the notion that a lawful gun owner can always stop a killer by shooting back.  After all, John McClane, Rambo, and Axel Foley always stop the villain in the end, so why can't we?

I totally agree with you, including the "gather dust" part. I was a Marine shooting instructor and team shooter and I have always advocated that if you absolutely must have a gun at home, make it a shotgun, although you'll never need it.

I call handguns and assault-type weapons "Roberts guns" in honor of the Supreme Court Chief Justice who warped the "militia" clause to allow every thug and psychopath to gather and legally own a murderous arsenal of military-grade weapons.

They were commercially produced starting in 1885, with a modern US design, the Remington Model 8, available in 1911. SA shotgun were commercially available starting in 1902, with the Browning model 5.
They are shooting bullets; into the ground; lots of noise; feeling of power. Like taking the OME muffler off a motorcycle so you can sound faster than the next guy. It's the hobby of extremes.

Buckshot isn't the answer.  Number 6 shot is.  It's not lethal after passing through sheet rock.  Put in a shotgun without a round in the chamber.  The sound of it being racked should deter any criminal.   It's far safer than any rifle or handgun.

It has happened. Happened just last week or so, a knife-wielding psychopath on a rampage started stabbing random people, and was stopped by a bystander who happened to have a gun.

http://www.abc4.com/content/news/top_stories/story/conceal-and-carry-sta...

You just don't hear about it because the body count is lower, as the attack stops shortly after it begins. Low body count = less press coverage.
It happens regularly, but it's not sensational.

I have no doubt that bad intentioned shooters have been stopped by people carrying guns.

...And that these scenarios happen about one out of every thousand scenarios where they don't happen.

Real life is not the movies. You are not omnipotent. You don't have the vigilance, reaction time, or ability in a confusing situation to clearly decide who must be stopped and do it in a fraction of a second before the damage is already done. Anyone sane and sober and not thinking they are Dirty Harry can reasonable work through the factors and understand this.

You can even see how well-intentioned individuals in a confusing situation can shoot other well-intentioned people holding a gun. In gun happy Tucson, surrounded by well-armed people, Gabby Giffords and others were not saved. No one is fast enough and equipped with preternatural foresight to do this saving. No one.

But if you are a member of the cult of the gun, your quasireligious faith in the gun to do good blocks all sense of reason on the subject. And so Hollywood fantasy thinking prevails instead.

In every mass shooting, we read that if only someone in the crowd had been carrying a concealed weapon, he could have shot back and killed the killer.

Well, why hasn't that scenario happened yet? Why have we yet to read about a lawful gun owner taking down a killer? Maybe because it's a fantasy based on Hollywood, where the hero faces a barrage of shots before shooting the villain with only one or two shots in return. Maybe because the choices really are that stark when you're being fired upon: either you get out of there and live, or you die on the spot.

I know how we really want to hope that when confronted by a killer, some brave soul will be able to shoot back, but it just isn't so.
